title: 108_hr2630
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" or the "CASE Act of 2003." It introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens who possess critical reliable information about alien smuggling organizations and are essential to criminal investigations. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" introduces amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding nonimmigrant visas for individuals involved in alien smuggling organizations. The amendments limit the number of visas issued to 400 per fiscal year and expand the authority of the Secretary of Homeland Security, Secretary of State, and Attorney General in determining essential information for criminal investigations. The amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act limit the number of nonimmigrant visas for alien smuggling organizations to 400 per fiscal year. The Secretary of Homeland Security, Secretary of State, and Attorney General have expanded authority to protect the identities of nonimmigrants and their family members if deemed necessary for security reasons. SEC. 3. Adjustment of status of nonimmigrant to that of person admitted for permanent residence. Section 245(j) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to adjust the status of a nonimmigrant admitted under a specific section to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence under certain conditions. The Secretary of Homeland Security can adjust the status of certain aliens to lawful permanent residents, including nonimmigrants admitted under a specific section, with the ability to protect the identity of the individual if necessary. SEC. 4. BRINGING IN AND HARBORING CERTAIN ALIENS. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase criminal penalties for bringing aliens into the US illegally, with potential for a 10-year sentence increase for certain criteria. Additionally, a rewards program is established to combat commercial alien smuggling. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase penalties for illegal alien smuggling, with a rewards program established by the Secretary of Homeland Security to assist in combating commercial alien smuggling involving groups of 10 or more aliens presenting life-threatening risks. The Secretary of State may offer rewards for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling, including those endangering lives or posing health risks in groups of 10 or more aliens. This program aims to dismantle smuggling organizations and identify key leaders. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this subsection, with ineligibility for government officials providing information while on duty. The Secretary of State may offer rewards for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling. Government officials providing information while on duty are not eligible for rewards. Protection measures can be taken to safeguard the identity of informants and their family members. Rewards under this program are capped at $100,000, unless authorized by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security can authorize rewards exceeding $50,000 to combat alien smuggling operations endangering lives or posing health risks. Rewards must be personally approved by the Secretary and certified for payment. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with other relevant authorities, will develop an outreach program to educate the public about penalties for alien smuggling and incentives for assisting in combating such operations.
